text: Personnel of the Hungarian People's Army marching in the City Park during the 1964 Liberation Day parade HPA artillery during 1961 Liberation Day parade The Liberation Day () in Hungary is celebrated on 4 April. It honors the Liberation of Hungary from the Nazi Germany during the Siege of Budapest and the broader Budapest Offensive by the Soviet Red Army.Cavendish, Marshall (2005), p. 114. On 4 April 1950, the Presidential Council of the Hungarian People's Republic declared Liberation Day to be the main national holiday in the socialist republic Every year on this day, they also remembered the Soviet soldiers who fell in Hungary. The commemoration of holiday included ceremonial meetings, wreath laying ceremonies at the Memorial Stone of Heroes (Hősök emlékköve). Every 5 years, a military parade of the Hungarian People's Army would be held on Hősök tere inside the City Park in honor of the holiday, the last of which being held in 1985 in the presence of General Secretary János Kádár, Defense Minister István Oláh and a Soviet delegation led by Vasili Kuznetsov.Edvard Beneš úton Kassa felé 1945. április 4-én a vonaton, televizio.skhttps://books.google.com/books?id=ATXjAAAAMAAJ&pg;=PA45&dq;=military+parade+in+warsaw+1985&hl;=en&sa;=X&ved;=0ahUKEwie56Tz- JDmAhUPTawKHRCmA3EQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q;=military%20parade%20in%20warsaw%201985&f;=false With the end of communism in Hungary approaching, the Council of Ministers of the Hungarian People's Republic removed the holiday from among its public holidays in 1989 and was abolished in 1991.
